                        The former Florida governor has suddenly became very bro. 

            By 
Nolan D. McCaskill

11/12/15 11:43 AM EST
Jeb Bush
column19: once the \"joyful tortoise\" playing the long game in the presidential race
column20:
has come out of his shell. What's emerged? Macho Jeb!
The former Florida governor has been reinventing himself as he seeks to calm his "nervous Nellie" donors concerned about his flailing poll numbers and a series of underwhelming debate performances. 
Story Continued Below
His campaign has rebooted with a "Jeb Can Fix It" slogan
column21: and the self-described introvert has gone on a bro spree
column22: trying to prove to voters that he has the guts and determination to dominate the still-unwieldy GOP field. \nHere are just a few ways Macho Jeb has made his mark in recent days:\n1. When a voter told Bush he was switching his support from Texas Sen. Ted Cruz to Bush
column23: the 6-foot-3 presidential candidate responded with an awkward chest bump. Bush didn't stop there. He's now offering chest bumps to any converts.\nCruz supporter tells Bush he's now backing him instead. Bush gives him a chest bump. pic.twitter.com/S201SJEabh\n\u2014 Ashley Killough (@KilloughCNN) November 12
column26:
he eats nails before breakfast. He even has the picture to prove it.
 
The waiters had a little fun with me this AM. #nailsforbreakfast pic.twitter.com/S2Zpb3I3Yr
— Jeb Bush (@JebBush) November 8
column27: 2015\n3. He\u2019s also handy. Give Bush just about any problem and #JebCanFixIt. The Bush campaign launched this initiative earlier this month
column28:
much to the delight of Twitter.
 
Is he running for President or Plumber? #JebCanFixIt pic.twitter.com/nn9QaXO6MS
— Carl J Gerber (@ConstantNSharp) November 2
column30: something on his to-do list in Iowa.\nTo-do list from the Iowa field office: pic.twitter.com/xViJLYvSMe\n\u2014 Jeb Bush (@JebBush) November 9
column32: pre-gaming for the fourth presidential debate with some competition on the bocce ball court. \nNew pre-debate ritual: Bocce ball. pic.twitter.com/J1aRyy5KuT\n\u2014 Jeb Bush (@JebBush) November 11
column33: 2015\n6. Bush is so tough that he would kill Baby Hitler
column34: a question first posed by New York Times Magazine: \u201cHell yeah
column36: \u201d Bush told Huffington Post this week. \u201cYou gotta step up
column37:
man.”
7. And let’s not forget his low-five with Donald Trump during September’s GOP debate.
 
via GIPHY

 © 2015 POLITICO LLC"

body: {"body": " White evangelical Christians are well-positioned to have a strong say in early 2016 Republican primaries and caucuses
byline: a new analysis by Geoffrey Skelley of Sabato\u2019s Crystal Ball found Thursday. But they could face trouble later in the campaign season.\nVoting starts February 1 in Iowa
description: where in 2012 exit poll data showed 56 percent of caucus voters were white evangelicals. Rick Santorum
title: the former U.S. senator from Pennsylvania
url: had a strong appeal to those voters
topics: and inched out a win.\nSkelley
people: using data from exit polls in 2008 and 2012
org: as well as information from the Census Bureau and the Public Religion Research Institute\u2019s American Values Atlas
election_confidence: found that 64 percent of total delegates in states with primaries or caucuses prior to March 8 will come from states with likely white evangelical majorities. South Carolina votes later in February
date_access: Arkansas
column17: Tennessee and Texas. Three more such states
column20: vote March 5.\nThat means that candidates with special appeal to those groups could get an early boost
column21: but it doesn\u2019t mean that will last. A majority of convention delegates will be chosenafter March 8.\n\u201cAll this is to say that white evangelical Christians are going to impact the 2016 Republican nomination contest
column22: just as they have in previous cycles
column23: \u201d Skelley found.\nBut because early delegates will be awarded proportionately
column24: it will be hard for any single candidate in a multi-candidate field to get a huge early lead. And after March 15
column25: some states will have winner take all primaries. And more states with smaller evangelical communities
column27: will be voting.\n\u201cThis is not to say that a white evangelical-oriented outsider candidate won\u2019t win the Republican nomination
column28: \u201d Skelley said. \u201cBut many states with large numbers of conservative born-again Christians will vote when many candidates may still be in the race
column30: if the white evangelical Iowa lane of the field winnows a great deal between now and March 1
column31: it\u2019s possible that someone could take advantage and rack up a solid delegate take. Only time will tell
column32: but there\u2019s little question that white evangelical Christians are going to be an important factor in determining the GOP nominee
column33: particularly in the early going.\u201d\nSo far
column34: retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson has attracted a strong evangelical following. Also in the mix are real estate mogul Donald Trump
column39: former governor of Arkansas and 2008 Iowa caucus winner
column43:
"description": "Analysis shows early states with big evangelical blocs
Appeal could fade as race moves to bigger states
Several candidates vying for evangelical vote
…
Click to Continue »"
column44: "title": "White evangelicals: Early influence on GOP race

body: {"body": "\u201cBen Carson just spent a week passing through an intense crucible over his biographical credibility. After Tuesday evening\u2019s good performance
byline: I\u2019d say Ben Carson isn\u2019t going to fade
description: \u201d writes our columnist Daniel Henninger. Other contenders aren\u2019t fading either
title: which leads Mr. Henninger to conclude that none of the GOP candidates \u201clooks likely to pull away and capture the majority of primary delegates before the party\u2019s nominating convention in Cleveland next July.\u201d\nClick here to receive WSJ Opinion headlines and commentary via email.\n\u201cWe\u2019ve been wondering all week what happened to the grown-ups on American university campuses
url: and it appears we have a sighting
topics: \u201d writes the editorial board. Purdue President  Mitch Daniels wrote to students and faculty to remind them of Purdue\u2019s determination to be \u201ca welcoming
org: where each person is respected and treated with dignity\u201d and also \u201cto be steadfast in preserving academic freedom and individual liberty. What a proud contrast to the environments that appear to prevail at places like Missouri and Yale.\u201d\nDon\u2019t believe bipartisan claims that lawmakers have reformed Social Security\u2019s disability insurance program
election_confidence: where beneficiaries and costs are surging. Andy Koenig points out that the recently enacted budget deal will save just $4.4 billion of the program\u2019s $340 billion projected shortfall over the next 10 years
authors: according to the Congressional Budget Office. \u201cTo cover up those structural problems
date_written: the budget deal transfers $117 billion from the Social Security Old Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund
article_id: who calls it \u201ca new twist on the government tradition of robbing Peter to pay Paul.\u201d\nAfter receiving endorsements from teachers unions
date_access: Hillary Clinton has abandoned her support for charter schools. \u201cMrs. Clinton\u2019s charter reversal suggests her Education Department would be a wholly owned union subsidiary. The losers will be the poor parents and children who Democrats claim to represent
column16: a three-pack-a-day smoker who served as Chancellor of West Germany from 1974 to 1982
column17: died this week at the age of 96. Josef Joffe recounts how he defeated terrorists without sacrificing individual liberty and stared down the Soviet Union by promoting the deployment of U.S. missiles in his country.\nKarl Rove says the \u201cbiggest loser\u201d of Tuesday night\u2019s debate was Donald Trump. \u201cAfter arguing for months that illegal immigration pushes down Americans\u2019 wages
column18: Mr. Trump said he opposes raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour. Wages
column22: adding that Americans would \u2018have to work really hard\u2019 for bigger paychecks.\u201d Mr. Rove adds that Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201cworst moment\u201d came when he attacked the Pacific trade deal
column23: \u201csaying that Chinese currency manipulation is \u2018not even discussed in the almost 6
column24: 000-page agreement.\u2019 Mr. Paul did the takedown: \u2018We might want to point out
column25: China is not part of this deal.\u2019 Laughter from the crowd.\u201d\nThe unelected California Air Resources Board has issued a new mandate to reduce the \u201ccarbon intensity\u201d of transportation fuels. Using more biofuels is one way to get around it
column26: but Jacob Borden points out that \u201cchanging California\u2019s gasoline is increasingly difficult. A federal mandate to blend renewable fuels has already pushed the ethanol content in most gasoline to the 10% limit tolerated by existing engine designs.\u201d\nIt\u2019s also increasingly difficult to get Americans to participate in a public-opinion survey. Michael Barone explains how changes in American habits and technology are making political polls less reliable."
column30: and a bipartisan fraud on Social Security reform."

body: {"body": " (CNN)Ted Cruz is facing criticism on the right over a surprising issue: immigration.\nThe senator from Texas and Republican presidential candidate
byline: who rose to national prominence because of his hard-line stands on everything from Obamacare to immigration
description: is under fire for his past support of the controversial H-1B visa program. \nCruz has backed quintupling the number of visas in the program
title: which encourages legal immigration for highly skilled foreign workers. But it's a position that's causing headaches for him as the campaign develops.  \n\"You've got Hillary Clinton
url: Jeb Bush
topics: Marco Rubio and even Ted Cruz
org: who want to do everything from double to triple to quintuple -- in Ted Cruz's case -- the number of H-1B visas that are available to these largely offshore outsourcing companies from India
election_confidence: \" influential conservative pundit Michelle Malkin said in a video on her Facebook page last week. \"That is nuts.\"  \nFor Cruz
authors: support for H-1B visas has been a way to insulate himself not just from a hot red base quick to label any moderation as amnesty
date_written: but also from his unwillingness to say what he would do with the 11 million undocumented immigrants in the United States. Sharing his father's dramatic flight from Cuba
orgs: Cruz tells reporters or town hall questioners that he \"celebrates legal immigration\" and that he would like to \"streamline\" the process -- even as he cracks down on illegal border crossings. \nBut Cruz appears to be changing his tune. During Tuesday night's Fox Business debate in Milwaukee
article_id: he framed illegal immigration as an economic threat
date_access: choosing the rhetoric used by conservative talk radio hosts who have raked Cruz over the coals
column15: rather than his tried-and-true stump speech about preserving rule of law. And Cruz now no longer supports an increase in the number of visas until the program is reformed
column16:
spokeswoman Catherine Frazier said Wednesday. 
Ted Cruz draws immigration contrast with Marco Rubio

The U.S. currently allows only 65
column17: 000 workers who specialize in science or technology to immigrate legally each year. But the program has come under increasing criticism from protectionists and American industries that say the country is \"outsourcing\" labor and charge there is widespread abuse of the visa system. \nCruz has of late been more loudly voicing objections to the visa process
column18: telling a New Hampshire voter in a town hall on Wednesday evening that the emerging reports are \"horrifying
column19: \" a shift he signaled in an interview with radio host Vince Coakley last week. \n\"I have been very
column20: very concerned at the growing abuse of the program
column21: \" Cruz said. \"That's not what the H-1B program was designed to do.\" \nThat interview made its way to Republican Sen. Jeff Sessions of Alabama
column22: perhaps the GOP's leading anti-immigration voice. Sessions said he is talking with Cruz about his current position and even hinted that Cruz could flip his position
column23: sounding skeptical that the senator from Texas would still want to quintuple the number of legal immigrants in the future. \n\"I think a lot of our members will come out that way in the end
column24: \" Sessions told CNN. \nCruz is hardly the only GOP candidate who backs the program on some level. Republicans from Bush to Ben Carson have voiced some support for H-1B visas
column25: and Rubio's push for a more ambitious
column26: Microsoft-backed bill has drawn the ire of Sessions
column27: who said Rubio's legislation would \"quash the dreams of more talented Americans.\" \n\nDonald Trump has already shown a willingness to mock Rubio for his aggressive support for the Silicon Valley-backed policy. Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski said the campaign is not planning to hit Cruz on the explosive issue
column28: but Trump's hard line on immigration has helped shift the debate to the right on the campaign trail. \nTakeaways from the Republican debate\nBut given Cruz's ideological purity -- highlighted by a report on Monday from Heritage Action
column29:
a political group tied to the influential Heritage Foundation -- his support for H-1Bs may be the most attractive liability to attack. 
Republican talkers have been Cruz's biggest gadflies. Cruz enjoys an unusually chummy relationship with conservative talk radio hosts -- joking before Tuesday night's debate that a leading trio in the industry should moderate future forums -- but some have turned on him. 
The New Hampshire voter told Cruz that her brother in the tech industry might not vote for him because of his position -- which the brother learned about from talk radio. 
"The rhetoric and the policy do not match
column30: \" Rick Santorum told CNN on Wednesday
column31: saying Cruz's motivation for increased legal immigration was \"purely political\" and an attempt to win over business-friendly donors. \"This is a way of having a foot in both camps -- to sound very tough on illegal immigration
column33: 'I'm going to take care of you by bringing in a whole bunch of people legally.'\"  \n\nThe unease with Cruz dates back to the 2013 Senate fight over immigration
column34: when Rubio and Democratic leaders led an ill-fated push for comprehensive reform legislation that included a path to citizenship for the undocumented. Cruz fought the bill
column35: but also argued for an amendment to increase in the cap on visas to 325
column37: a position he has repeated during the 2016 race. \nBut after the 2013 bill died and the dust settled
column38: Cruz continued to be excoriated by some of the movement's leading talkers for his stance.\n\"I don't care how many times Ted Cruz is held up by the tea party. Ted Cruz is identical to Marco Rubio
column39: \" radio host Michael Savage told his listeners in January 2014. \"Ted Cruz is not to be trusted. I told you he's a snake.\" \nCruz's critics on the issue see room for hope: Cruz does not bring up the specific fivefold increase as often as he once did
column40: opting for vaguer rhetoric. He chided donors and reporters in Tuesday night's debate for not seeing immigration as a pocketbook issue as opposed to a cultural one. And his radio interview last week could foreshadow the package of reforms that Sessions said Cruz is likely to introduce in the Senate over the coming months. \nRoy Beck
column42: a group supporting a reduction in immigration numbers
column43: predicted that while Cruz is \"polishing some of the edges\" with his new language
column44: his support for expanded H-1Bs would be used a political wedge to expose \"his real vulnerable spot.\" \nUnless
column46: Cruz changes his position. \n\"I just see him month by month and shifting
column48: you could end up being in a really different place than nine months ago.\"\n \n"
column50: "description": "Ted Cruz is facing criticism on the right over a surprising issue: immigration."
column51: "title": "Why some conservatives are upset with Cruz on immigration"

byline: which concentrates on growth as it tries to keep step in a corporate-computing market transformed by the cloud

 which sells PCs and printers

body: {"body": "After a week of debate over whether Ben Carson really won a scholarship to West Point
byline: Republicans have refocused the question of military service on Hillary Rodham Clinton
description: expressing doubts about her claim that she tried to join the Marines in the 1970s.\n\nThe matter came up after an event in New Hampshire this week
title: when Mrs. Clinton
url: the front-runner for the Democratic presidential nomination
topics: shared a story with voters about her interest as a young woman in becoming a Marine.\n\n\u201cHe looks at me and he goes
org: how old are you?'\u201d Mrs. Clinton recalled. \u201cI said
election_confidence: \u2018Well
article_id: that\u2019s kind of old for us.\u2019 He says to me
date_access: \u2018Maybe the dogs will take you
column15: \u2019 meaning the Army.\u201d\n\nRepublicans are suggesting that the story is an embellishment
column16: as Mrs. Clinton would have been seeking to join the military in 1975
column17: the year she married Bill Clinton in Fayetteville
column18: Ark.\n\nThe story of Mrs. Clinton\u2019s military aspirations has come up before
column19: as have questions about her honesty\u00a0on the subject. In 1994
column20: The New York Times\u2019s Maureen Dowd noted that joining the military seemed to clash with the future first lady\u2019s persona:\n\nAfter all
column21: Hillary Rodham was an up-and-coming legal star involved with an up-and-coming political star. She had made a celebrated appearance in Life magazine as an anti-establishment commencement speaker at Wellesley College
column23: as president of the student government
column24:
she had organized teach-ins on her opposition to the Vietnam War.

Mrs. Clinton’s campaign did not respond to questions about the circumstances of her application to the Marines.

“G.I. Hillary?” the Republican National Committee wrote in an email that suggested she had a pattern of fudging her biography. “Clinton’s claim that she tried to join the Marines doesn’t add up.”

While running for president in 2008
column25: Mrs. Clinton faced an uproar after she said that her plane landed under sniper fire during a 1996 trip to Bosnia. In fact
column26: she was greeted by children rather than bullets.\n\nOn Thursday
column28: who was the Republican presidential nominee that year
column29: suggested that Mrs. Clinton might have misremembered trying to join the Marines.\n\n\u2014 John McCain (@SenJohnMcCain) November 12

column33: Republicans mocked a claim by Hillary Rodham Clinton that she tried to join the Marines in the 1970s."

body: {"body": "Washington  (CNN)Pledging to spend more money on the military was once an easy way for Republican presidential candidates to showcase their conservative bona fides.\nNot anymore.\nThe feud among Republicans over what it means to be a national security conservative was on clear display at this week's presidential debate
byline: where Rand Paul
description: the Kentucky senator known for his libertarian leanings and non-interventionist foreign policy views
title:
dug into Florida Sen. Marco Rubio over his plans to increase the defense budget by $1 trillion over the next 10 years without explaining how he would pay for the increase.
"How is it conservative to add a trillion dollars in military expenditures?" Rand Paul asked his opponent at Tuesday's Republican debate. "You cannot be a conservative if you're going to keep promoting new programs that you're not going to pay for."
Rubio retorted swiftly: "We can't even have an economy if we're not safe." 
The heated exchange exposed the fault lines in the GOP as conservatives grapple with a world that seems increasingly in turmoil and a country weighed down by mounting debt.
It also raises questions about the definition of a conservative national security policy
url: where two of the ideology's traditional tenets -- a strong U.S. military and reduced government spending -- collide. Rubio and Rand are each trying to claim the mantle of being the \"true conservative\" in an appeal to GOP primary voters
topics: even though they take sharply opposing views on the issue.\nREAD: Takeaways from the Republican debate\nBoth senators' approaches have footholds in American conservatism
people: and which one ends up resonating more with voters could be as much a product of the current international security environment as ideological imperatives.\nPeter Berkowitz
org: a senior fellow at the conservative Hoover Institution
election_confidence: described \"a very difficult balancing act\" for Republicans between the instinct for fiscal restraint and the deep-rooted conservative tradition of a strong national defense.\n\"There's something in my mind worrisome and off in declaring what the authentic conservative position is
authors: \" Berkowitz said. \"The better way to characterize the tradition is really an unending debate between these two sides.\"\nPaul and Rubio's views on U.S. defense spending are each aligned with two different Republican presidents: Dwight Eisenhower
date_access: according to fellow Hoover Institution scholar Kori Schake
column15: a National Security Council aide in President George W. Bush's administration.\n\"There is really an enduring tension between the two
column16: but it is certainly true that at least since Ronald Reagan
column17: the reflexes of conservatism are for more defense spending
column19: \" Schake said.\nSchake said that Paul's arguments in favor of fiscal restraint might have gained more traction three years ago when conservatives accepted steep defense cuts as part of \"sequestration\" to hold down the cost of the U.S. budget. But now
column22: instability in the Middle East and a more aggressive Russian posture are making a strong defense a priority for most conservatives.\n\"The world is looking a lot more dangerous and uncertain for America's safety in the last two
column24: \" Schake said. \"I do think there is an increased appreciation even among debt hawks that we want a wider margin of error
column25: we want a stronger military in order to deter challenges to America's security.\"\nBut Christopher Preble
column26: the vice president for defense and foreign policy studies at the libertarian Cato Institute
column27: said he believes Rubio's plan to increase defense spending without offsetting the cost is simply \"not a conservative sentiment at all.\"\nAnd while the Republican foreign policy establishment has largely embraced the neoconservative belief in an aggressive American military stance abroad
column28: Preble said he believes that ideology represents a \"very small segment of the public at large
column29: including the Republican electorate.\"\nBut an August 2014 Pew Research Center poll showed that a slim majority of Americans believed Obama's foreign policy approach is \"not tough enough\" -- a figure that soared to 81% among conservatives.\nNorman Ornstein
column30: a political analyst at the neoconservative American Enterprise Institute
column31: suggested Paul's argument in favor of a more scaled-down military will face significant headwinds since the GOP has pressed its message that Obama is too weak on the world stage and in confronting ISIS.\nInstead
column32: Ornstein said Rubio probably \"had the upper hand\" in the debate
column33: with Rubio's hawkish position likely to be more attractive.\nREAD: Rand Paul: Clinton
column34: Rubio both 'neoconservatives'\n\"The antipathy toward Obama is so great
column36: you want to be the opposite of X. So if the narrative in almost every case is Obama is getting taken to the cleaners by (Russian President Vladimir) Putin
column37: Obama is unable to deal with ISIS
column38: unable to deal with China and you're out there saying I'm not going to do that -- that will probably help.\"\nIndeed
column39: it's a calculation that most in the Republican field have made. Beyond Rubio
column40: nearly every candidate from Jeb Bush to Chris Christie to Donald Trump has pledged to adapt a more robust posture in fighting ISIS and to build a stronger military to do so.\nBut both Rubio and his like-minded rivals as well as Paul have some claim to the conservative movement's sentiments on foreign policy. That's largely because views on foreign policy are in no way homogenous within the movement.\nIn Ornstein's word
column41: on foreign policy there simply isn't a \"one-size-fits-all conservative mantle. \nAnd James Carafano
column42: vice president for foreign and defense policy studies at the conservative Heritage Foundation
column43: said Rubio and Paul's arguments are not necessarily incompatible.\n\"We had this kind of caricature of foreign policy that the choice in foreign policy is between invading everybody and every country or sitting at home and doing nothing
column44: \" Carafano said. \"I don't think that reflects the mainstream of where conservatives really are
column45: and I don't think that really reflects where the major candidates really are.\"\nHe concluded
column46: \"The reality of foreign policy is there is not a rule book
column47: and there is not a philosophical or ideological answer for every foreign policy problem.\"\n"
column50: "title": "Can a conservative spend $1 trillion on defense?"

body: {"body": "WASHINGTONTwo U.S. consumer groups announced the formation of a coalition with New York labor unions on Thursday to press antitrust regulators to oppose big insurance mergers that would cut the number of nationwide for-profit health insurers from five to three.\nThe Coalition to Preserve Patient Choice
byline: made up of the Consumer Federation of America
description: Consumer Action and others
title: was formed because of concern about Anthem Inc's purchase of Cigna Corp for $47 billion and Aetna Inc's decision to buy Humana Inc for $37 billion
url: the group said in a statement.\n\"The CPPC believes these mergers should be challenged or patient choice will suffer.\u00a0In fact
topics: studies have shown previous health insurance mergers resulted in (price) increases ranging from 7 percent to nearly 14 percent
people: \" the group said. \u00a0\nAnthem said in a statement that the coalition's assertions were \"misleading
org: \" and that it was \"confident that the transaction\u2019s consumer benefits will be understood by state and federal regulators.\"\nAetna said in a statement that its deal for Humana was \"primarily about the Medicare marketplace
election_confidence: where there is robust competition and choice. We are confident that our transaction will receive a fair
authors: thorough and fact-based review from the Department of Justice and the states.\"\nThe deals are being reviewed by the U.S. Department of Justice and state insurance regulators
date_written: and have been the subject of hearings in Congress. They have also been criticized by Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
orgs:
who said last month that she is "very skeptical" the mergers would be good for consumers.
The American Medical Association has asked for the deals to be blocked while the American Hospital Association has also been critical of them.


 (Reporting by Diane Bartz; Editing by Marguerita Choy and Tom Brown)"

body: {"body": "A long-simmering debate over immigration in the Republican presidential contest boiled over on Thursday
byline: as five contenders seized on the issue and Senator Ted Cruz accused his colleague
description: Senator Marco Rubio
title: of \u201ctrying to stuff amnesty down the throats of the American people.\u201d\n\nFrom appearances on conservative talk radio to the campaign trail in South Carolina
url: the candidates sought to appeal to grass-roots conservatives who are alarmed about immigration. And the eruption of open warfare between Mr. Rubio and Mr. Cruz
topics: two establishment candidates who have been rising in the polls
people: showed the likely contours of the Republican presidential fight as it hurtles toward the Iowa caucuses in less than 90 days.\n\nImmigration is a key vulnerability for Mr. Rubio
org: who was initially part of an effort in 2013 to formulate a bipartisan bill in the Senate to reform the immigration system
election_confidence: an effort that is viewed with deep skepticism by conservatives.\n\nMr. Cruz
authors: in an appearance with the conservative radio host Laura Ingraham
date_written: denounced Mr. Rubio without using his name
article_id: \u201cYou know where someone is based on their actions. As the Scripture says
date_access: you shall know them based on their fruits.\u201d\n\nAnd three other lower-polling candidates \u2014 Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky; Rick Santorum
column15: a former Pennsylvania senator; and Carly Fiorina
column16: a former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard \u2014 sought to join the fight
column17: piling on Mr. Rubio or Mr. Cruz as insufficiently pure on a key litmus test for segments of the Republican base.\n\nThe long-distance exchanges illustrated the degree to which several candidates see immigration
column18: which emerged as a key issue in the 2014 midterm elections
column19: as the most potent weapon in their arsenal in a presidential contest that has been characterized by concerns about the direction of the country.\n\nMr. Rubio
column20: when asked about Mr. Cruz\u2019s critique while campaigning Thursday morning
column21: sought to turn the tables.\n\n\u201cTed is a supporter of legalizing people that are in this country illegally
column23: according to a transcript provided by his aides. \u201cIn fact
column24: when the Senate bill was proposed
column25: he proposed legalizing people that were here illegally. He proposed giving them work permits. He\u2019s also supported a massive expansion of the green cards.\n\n\u201cHe supported a massive expansion of the H-1B program
column29: I don\u2019t think our positions are dramatically different. I do believe that we have to deal with immigration reform in a serious way
column30: and it begins by proving to people that illegal immigration is under control.\u201d\n\nIn his criticism of his Senate colleague
column31: Mr. Cruz recalled that Mr. Rubio
column32: the Florida senator who was a member of the so-called Gang of Eight group of lawmakers who sought to overhaul the immigration system
column33: opposed measures to tighten border security.\n\n\u201cHe opposed every single one of them
column36: said of amendments Mr. Rubio opposed that would have increased border-patrol resources
column37: created a strong e-verify system and developed an exit-entry system for visa overstays. \u201cThe Gang of Eight voted against securing and enforcing the border.\u201d\n\nMr. Rubio now says that immigration must be handled in parts and that after the border is secured
column38: new policies can be developed for dealing with immigrants who have entered the country illegally. He is not in favor of deporting undocumented immigrants en masse
column39: as some of his rivals propose."
column41: "description": "The long-distance exchanges illustrated the degree to which several Republican candidates see immigration as the most potent weapon in the presidential contest."
column42: "title": "Immigration Fight Boils Over as Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio Battle"

body: {"body": "Senator Ted Cruz continued to pound Senator Marco Rubio over his immigration record on Thursday
byline: escalating the tension between the two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. \n\nSpeaking on Laura Ingraham\u2019s radio program
description: Mr. Cruz reiterated his view that Mr. Rubio is weak when it comes to immigration.\n\n\u201cTalk is cheap
title: \u201d the Texas senator said. \u201cYou know where someone is based on their actions. As the Scripture says
url: you shall know them based on their fruits.\u201d\n\nMr. Cruz went on to recall that Mr. Rubio
topics: the Florida senator who was a member of the so-called Gang of Eight group of lawmakers who sought to overhaul the immigration system
people: opposed measures to tighten border security. \n\n\u201cHe opposed every single one of them
org: \u201d Mr. Cruz said of amendments Mr. Rubio opposed that would have increased border patrol resources
election_confidence: created a strong e-verity system and an developed exit-entry system for visa overstays. \u201cThe Gang of Eight voted against securing and enforcing the border.\u201d\n\nMr. Rubio now says that immigration must be handled in parts and that after the border is secured new policies can be developed for dealing with immigrants who have entered the country illegally. He is not in favor of deporting undocumented immigrants en masse
authors: as some of his rivals propose.  \n\nMr. Cruz\u2019s comments come as he has been running close with Mr. Rubio in many polls and as they are increasingly competing for attention from conservative voters. At an event in New Hampshire on Wednesday night
date_written: Mr. Cruz suggested that picking a nominee who favors \u201camnesty\u201d would damage his party\u2019s prospects in a general election.\n\n\u201cIn my view
orgs: if Republicans nominate for president a candidate who supports amnesty
article_id: we will have given up one of the major distinctions with Hillary Clinton and we will lose the general election
date_access: \u201d he said. \u201cThat is a path to losing.\u201d\n\nIn spite of his tough talk on immigration
column15: some Republicans think that it is Mr. Cruz whose actions do not match his words. Rick Santorum
column17: said on Thursday that Mr. Cruz\u2019s support for expanding the H1-B visa program for skilled workers without reforms would harm American workers. \n\n\u201cCruz tough on immigration?\u201d Mr. Santorum\u2019s campaign said in an email. \u201cNot so fast!\u201d "
column19: "description": "Immigration reform continues to be a sticking point between two of the Republican senators running for president
column20: with Ted Cruz saying that selecting a nominee who supports amnesty
column22: \u201cis a path to losing\u201d the general election."

body: {"body": "Sarah R. Coleman is a Ph.D. candidate in history at Princeton University and a fellow at the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia. \n (CNN)In Tuesday night's GOP debate
byline: Donald Trump turned to history to provide a model for his plan to deport 11 million undocumented immigrants
description: saying
title: \"Let me just tell you that Dwight Eisenhower
url: good president
topics: great president. ... Moved a million and a half illegal immigrants out of this country
people: moved them just beyond the border. They came back. Moved them again
org: beyond the border
election_confidence: they came back. Didn't like it. Moved them way south. They never came back. Dwight Eisenhower.\"\nWhile not calling it by name
date_written: \" which Trump claims significantly reduced unlawful immigration in the early 1950s. Here's the problem: It wasn't \"successful\" then
article_id: and is not a model for a considered immigration policy now.  It was an inhumane program that sheds a harsh light on the supposedly tranquil Fifties and casts doubt on Trump's judgment.\nWith rising domestic political concern about illegal Mexican immigration in the early 1950s
date_access: President Eisenhower turned to his Immigration and Naturalization Service commissioner
column15: and his former West Point classmate
column17: to undertake Operation Wetback \u2014 named for the derogatory term for Mexican immigrants that dates to the 1920s \u2014 with the cooperation and assistance of the Mexican government as historians have shown. \nIn a military-style action
column18: beginning in June 1954 and continuing through 1955
column19: immigration agents throughout the Southwest and
column21: other parts of the United States
column22: rounded up immigrants without legal status. The deportation program also had something Donald Trump might have loved \u2014 extensive publicity
column23: as immigration officers were followed and photographed by journalists courted by government officials.\nINS agents began by blanketing communities with public notices encouraging undocumented workers to leave on their own accord
column24: then soon turned to harsher methods
column25: including sweeps and raids using jeeps
column26: planes and ground teams. \nAs historian Mae Ngai related
column27: while some immigrants were transported by plane or train to Mexico
column28: a quarter of those deported were transported on cargo boats from Port Isabel
column32: in an operation that a congressional investigation \u2014 convened in 1956 \u2014 compared to an \"18th century slave ship\" and a \"penal hell ship.\"  \nCramped into inhumane sleeping spaces
column36: a riot broke out on one ship
column37: and seven immigrants drowned on another.  Eighty-eight immigrants died of sunstroke during a roundup in 112-degree heat
column38: while others were loaded tightly on trucks
column39: driven south to Mexico and dumped in the desert. While the INS at the time claimed that the six-week operation netted 1.3 million deportations
column40: scholars have suggested the numbers were far less.  \nDespite the U.S. government's major efforts
column41: Operation Wetback was unsuccessful at curbing future unauthorized migration to the United States. At the same time
column43: which was the main goal of the INS
column44: which wanted to encourage farmers to hire workers legally through the \"Bracero\" program
column45: which allowed temporary contract workers to enter the United States.  \nBetween 1953 and 1955
column46: INS more than doubled the number of Bracero visas and many of those legally contracted workers had previously worked illegally.  The Bracero program itself was marked by widespread abuse of workers. \nWhere immigration policy is concerned
column47: Eisenhower is not the president to emulate
column48: regardless of where one stands on the political spectrum.\nOperation Wetback is just one of many shameful episodes of forceful removal in American history
column50: when members of several Native American nations were forcibly removed from their traditional lands and relocated farther west during the 19th century
column51: to the forced relocation and incarceration of over 100
column52: 000 Japanese Americans during World War II.\n Like those events
column53: Operation Wetback was a shameful violation of human rights
column54: not a model for future policy.  \nJoin us on Facebook.com/CNNOpinion.Read CNNOpinion's Flipboard magazine.\n"

{"body": " Donald Trump suggested it’s time for some of his rivals to drop out of the presidential race as he returned to Iowa Thursday amid some polls that show his numbers flattening in the first-in-the nation state.
The standing room-only rally at a local community college was Trump’s first appearance in the state since Tuesday’s debate and he told the crowd he’s hopeful that some of “the guys on the end” get out of the presidential race.
“Why are these people staying? George Pataki?” Trump said of the former New York governor. “He’s got nothing.”
Lindsey Graham? “He talks tough
byline: but we\u2019ll end up with World War II over Syria
description: \u201d Trump charged. Marco Rubio he called \u201cweak like a baby on immigration.\u201d\nHe told the crowd in a free-wheeling
title: hour-plus speech that as president he\u2019d restore \u201cMerry Christmas\u201d and \u201cbomb the sh&*\u201d out of the Islamic State.\n\u201dWe can\u2019t allow people to cut off peoples\u2019 heads
url: \u201d he said. \nHe panned President Barack Obama\u2019s decision to send 50 forces to work with local forces in Syria: \u201c50 sounds ridiculous. \u201cIf you\u2019re going to do something
topics: do it. Or don\u2019t do it.\u201d\nAnd he cited unpredictability as a qualification for president
people: criticizing Obama for announcing that he would send the troops into Syria.\n\u201cWe need really tough
org: smart people or we\u2019re not going to have a country left
election_confidence: \u201d he said."

body: {"body": "Republican and Democratic presidential candidates are divided over the handling of racially-charged protests at the University of Missouri and Yale University.\nRepublican presidential hopeful Ben Carson accused colleges and universities of being \"a little too tolerant\" and accepting of \"infantile behavior\" in the wake of separate episodes of racially-tinged unrest at the University of Missouri and Yale University
byline: Carson\u2019s undergraduate alma mater.\nSpeaking on \"The Kelly File\" on Fox News Wednesday night
description: Carson said the demonstrations on the two campuses and their aftermath is symptomatic of what\u2019s wrong with the nation\u2019s discourse.\n\"It's part of the problem that's going on in our country right now
title: \" said Carson
url: a retired neurosurgeon who leads the Republican presidential field in several key polls. \"We have people who get in their respective corners and demonize each other but there's no conversation. And of course
topics: if you ask people to put on the record what their gripes are and what their solutions are
people: then perhaps they can see that maybe they are not so far apart and they can come up with some reason or solutions.\"\nMeanwhile
org: Sen. Bernie Sanders
election_confidence: I-Vt.
authors: who\u2019s seeking the Democratic presidential nomination tweeted Thursday: \u201cI'm listening to the #BlackOnCampus conversation. It's time to address structural racism on college campuses.\u201d\nFormer Secretary of State Hillary Clinton\u2019s Democratic presidential campaign retweeted a message Thursday from one of her staffers
orgs: that said \u201cRacism has no place anywhere
article_id: let alone an institution of learning. Standing w/ the students at Mizzou in my home state calling for change.\u201d\nAt Missouri
date_access: university system President Tim Wolfe resigned Monday under pressure from students and faculty who said that he failed to respond to what they described as a racially intolerant atmosphere on the Columbia
column16:
campus. 
Demonstrations and protests boiled to the point the university’s football team threatened not to play a game until Wolfe was gone as president.

Their demands
column17: they're like crazy. The demands that they're - the things that they're asking for
column18: many of those things are -- like -- crazy! So it is just disgraceful Donald Trump on protesting students at the University of Missouri\nRepublican presidential candidate Donald Trump
column19: speaking on Fox Business News\u2019 \u201cMorning with Maria\u201d Thursday
column20: called the resignation of Wolfe and a faculty member at Missouri \u201cdisgusting.\u201d\n\u201cI think the two people that resigned are weak
column22: \u201d Trump said. \u201cI think that when they resigned they set something in motion that's going to be a disaster for the next long period of time. They were weak ineffective people. How we hire people like this -- Trump should have been the chancellor of that university. Believe me
column23: there would have been no resignation.\u201d \nAt Yale
column24: minority students have railed against what they say is a culturally-insensitive atmosphere on the New Haven
column26: campus triggered by accusations that black women weren\u2019t admitted to a party and an email message from a university official urging students not to take offense to some potentially insensitive Halloween costumes\n\nI know the President of Yale and he's a very
column27: very reasonable person. And you know
column28: I would imagine that he's working overtime right now to try to establish some dialogue Ben Carson on protests at Yale University\n Carson
column30: said the situations at Missouri and Yale were cases of \"just raw emotion\" and people being \"manipulated\" by \"outside forces who wish to create disturbances.\"\n\"Well
column31: we're being a little bit too tolerant
column35: \" Carson told Fox News\u2019 Megyn Kelly. \"And I don't care which side it comes from. You know
column36: to say that I have the right to violate your civil rights
column37: because you're offending me is un- American. It's unconstitutional. And the officials at these places must recognize that and have the moral courage to stand up to it. Because if they don't
column40: as we will move much further toward anarchy than anybody can imagine and much more quickly.\"\nCarson said \"we must encourage open dialogue\" and likened what\u2019s happened at Missouri and Yale to the end of a failing marriage.\n\"You know
column41: it\u2019s the same thing that happens before people get a divorce
column42: \" he said. \"They stopped talking. The next thing you know their spouse is a devil incarnate. That\u2019s what\u2019s going on. And we cannot allow that in America.\"\nWilliam Douglas: 202-383-6026
